summary.p: This is the second volume, after Indien 474, of the Tēmpāvaṇi copy owned by Edouard Ariel. The organization of this volume differs from the second volume of the 1851-3 editio princeps of the Tēmpāvaṇi insofar as it includes an additional canto (kuḻavikaḷvataippaṭalam), which in the printed editon appears in the third volume.

supportDesc.foliation: Each folio in the text is marked with a Tamil number on the r.m. of the the recto, added by the original scribe, and with a later roman numeration in pencil on the l.m. The scribe begun each canto on a new side of the folio, so we usually have a smaller number of lines in the folios containing the end of a canto.

additions.desc: An invocation to the Holy Family ends the ms. (see fol. 267v l.8 transcribed above).
The ms. contains several ink annotations.

Often, the number of a canto is written in ink next to its title [as in fol. 10r r.m., for instance]. We also find the following notes:
fol. 187r r.m. Le 19 mai 1841
fol. 197r r.m. Le 27 mai 1841
fol. 205r u.m. itil reṇṭu pāṭṭum iraṇṭuraiyum cērntiru{kki}ṟatu ("two verses and two commentaries have been added in this [place]"
f. 209r r.m. Le 3 juin 1841
These dates seem to mark the point in the text where a reader stopped reading. In the case of the Tamil note, the reader was clearly comparing this manuscript with another version of the text that either he had in mind, or in fron of him (as, for instance, in another manuscript copy). Who was this reader? It could not have been Ariel, who was not yet in India in 1841 (he arrived in 1844). If, as it seems to me, the French and Tamil annotations are written in the same hand and with the same ink, he might have some bilingual Catholic scholar from Pondicherry.
